#Text=Wikinews interviews author and filmmaker John Gaspard
#Text=Wednesday , March 19 , 2008
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=held an exclusive interview with author and filmmaker John Gaspard .
#Text=His films Resident Alien , Beyond Bob and Grown Men , besides opening to positive critical response , were all made on very low budgets ; costing around US$ 30,000 .
#Text=He says this is because " I despise the process of trying to raise money to finance movies .

column3:

#Text=was recently awarded the  Best Feature " award at the Forx Film Festival ; it also received an Honorable Mention at the Seventh Annual George Lindsey UNA Film Festival , and a Bronze Award at the WorldFest Houston .

column1: #Text=Grown Men

#Text=is a digital feature , consisting of five interlocking stories from four Minnesota writers : Rewired by David Fields , It ’s A Date and The Late Mrs. Boynton by John Gaspard , The $ 1,000 Wedding by Tom Poole , and Red Velvet Handcuffs by Matthew G. Anderson .
#Text=Grown Men
#Text=premiered at the Ashland Independent Film Festival .
#Text=It was named " Best of the Fest - Best Feature Screenplay " at the Black Point Film Festival in Lake Geneva .
#Text=It was also featured at the New York International Independent Film & Video Festival ; the Waterfront Film Festival ; the Oxford Film Festival ; and the Tambay Film Festival .
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=: You 're the author and co-author of several books , most notably Digital Filmmaking 101 . Tell us about them . What inspires you to write ?
#Text=Mr. Gaspard :
#Text=We wrote Digital Filmmaking 101 originally as a series of notes to ourselves , to remind us of the steps we took to make a feature for very little money .
#Text=We later expanded those notes into a complete book to provide beginning filmmakers with the tools they would need to make a feature for what most Hollywood films spend on coffee and rolls .

#Text=My second book , Fast , Cheap and Under Control : Lessons Learned From the Greatest Low-Budget Movie of All Time , was designed to help keep new filmmakers from re-inventing the wheel every time they go out to make a feature .
#Text=There is a wealth of knowledge in the low-budget movies that have come before ours , and it 's a foolish filmmaker who does n't heed those lessons .
#Text=In the book I talked to both old-school low-budget filmmakers ( like Roger Corman ) and people from the current generation ( Swingers , The Blair Witch Project , Open Water , etc. ) .
#Text=The latest book , Fast , Cheap and Written that Way : Top Screenwriters on Writing for Low-Budget Movies , does just what the title suggests .
#Text=I spoke to over twenty top screenwriters who had previously worked on low-budget films and got their secrets on how to write for a tiny budget .
#Text=Interviewees included George Romero , Tom DiCillo , Stuart Gordon , Bob Clark and Kenneth Lonnergan , among others .
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=: Your films were made on very low budgets . Grown Men cost under $ 13,000 . How did you manage this ?
#Text=Mr. Gaspard :
#Text=Well , as soon as you realize that you wo n't be paying anyone , that cuts your costs significantly .
#Text=Second , you should write the script to conform to locations and props that you can get for free .
#Text=Third , you should shoot as quickly as you can -- 12 to 15 pages of script a day is not uncommon .
#Text=The main reason to make a movie for such little money is not just to save money -- it 's also to help you maintain control of the movie .
#Text=Without backers breathing down your neck , you can make the movie you want at the pace you want .

#Text=You may never see that money again -- a high percentage of low-budget movies never see the light of day , let along turn a profit -- but the satisfaction of making the movie YOU wanted to make greatly outweighs the cost .
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=: Will you be doing anymore films in the near future ?
#Text=Mr. Gaspard :
#Text=We 're mulling over some script ideas , but currently do n't have anything we 're dying to do .
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=:
#Text=Do you have any advice for the amateur filmmakers reading this ?
#Text=Mr. Gaspard :
#Text=See as many movies as you can -- low-budget independent films , Hollywood films , classic movies from the Golden Era .
#Text=You can learn something valuable from every movie you watch , so the more you see the more you learn .
#Text=Read scripts to learn how to write one .
#Text=And I mean real scripts , not transcriptions of finished movies .
#Text=Learn what the words look like on the page and how that gets translated into images on the screen .
#Text=And , most important , do n't ever try to fund your movie with credit cards .
#Text=Do n't believe what you read about other filmmakers doing this -- it flat out does n't work .
#Text=Happy filmmaking !
